comments.commentBody: For some students, state schools are not as affordable as private schools - state schools don't have the endowments and tend to lack the backing of the state legislators to increase spending on higher education and to ear mark some of the increase for scholarships.  And, sadly, an awful lot of public school graduates feel their taxes are doing the job of paying for the present day student's education and therefor they don't feel the obligation and the need to give generously to their school's endowments - education is not a priority in this country and public education, even at the higher ed level, is sadly lagging in the economic means necessary to attract top notch students who need aid.  Some of those horror stories that are being told about huge student debt loads are being told about students who have attended public universities.  Sad but true, in some cases, the least expensive education may be obtain at a private university with a sizable endowment and a commitment to aiding students who need financial assistance.  Public universities are not known for need-blind admissions or have the where with all to institute such a policy.

Hate to be the contrarian her, it's easy to hate someone who punches his wife, but doesn't the wife have a say in the matter? Isn't she the victim in this whole thing? Is the NFL going to give here a stipend to replace her husband's lost income? Is the NFL making her a victim again?

Couldn't the NFL make Rice build a shelter for battered women from his salary? His wife obviously loves him and has stood by him, and this can only make things worse FOR HER because now she has a husband who's unemployable.

Wouldn't it be better to have a period of atonement and reparations?

The NFL let Michael Vick back in the game and he tortured and killed animals and went to prison. I think this whole thing has to be reconsidered with common sense and not knee-jerk reactions to click bait on the Net.

@Liz S.: hurting either one is 100% wrong, but in the dogs' case, they didn't have a choice to be in that situation. Rice's finacee/wife does have a choice.

Animals are effectively defenseless when they are being abused (and make no mistake, dog fighting is a form of abuse, plain and simple). Humans, at least, can tell someone, press charges, get out. Which is exactly what she should do.
It always blows my mind that any part of the NFL can be considered "non-profit."
Why are we even talking about the NFL. This was a vicious attack that left the victim unconscious.  Mr. Rice should be punished to the full extent of the law, regardless of what the NFL does.
I'm with you but your analysis misses the point. Rice's was a criminal act, an asault, pure and simple. Nothing to do with the game or any other excuses. An assault.

For everyone wondering why doesn't the victim just doesn't leave the abuser- please read some comments from Domestic violence hotline here. No one has walked in another's shoes but you'll get a perspective.

http://www.thehotline.org/2013/09/is-change-possible-in-an-abuser/#comments

(I believe it is ok to post the link to comments because the site is public).
For the sake of big money and image...two lousy reasons for Goodell, Harbaugh and the league to sell their ethics and their souls. Sad.
Goodell should be gone along with Ray Rice. He buried his head in the sand.

Many of them were abused as children, and have complicated emotional reactions. Not to mention that their self-esteem is often worn down by their dominating partner. Sometimes they also feel financial dependence on the partner. There's some great research on this in psychology, under the topic of "learned helplessness."

Apparently Ray Rice looks up to Janay's father.  She is probably under a lot of pressure from all sides, including her own family, to stay with him and shut up.  She is also very young, and the mother of his toddler. Where is she going to get the emotional and financial support to leave him?
It will never cease to amaze me that there are women who stay with violent men.  I hope she's in counseling too.

Don't kid yourself about the "different communities and countries" malarkey. Most well-to-do college students are from the elite, and they end up doing very little of use in those countries. Africa is not in better shape because well to do Americans and Europeans go to have a six-week experience. Stomping around European capitals and yawning at painted canvases on a guided tour for a week is not that broadening either.

Romney, like GW Bush, are not particularly bright guys, they lack curiosity, are lacking culture and frankly if it were not for their wealthy & well connected fathers they would never have been admitted into an Ivy league college and in Bush's case I suspect even a local community college would have been a stretch for him. Romney, Bush & Cheney all were exempt from the draft during Vietnam…..they had better things to do of course which did not include getting actual comprehensive educations.

I think universities today should, in addition to providing real academic rigor, help students build broad foundations rather than walls and ceilings. I think some schools are doing an excellent job of encouraging students to travel, live, learn and work in different communities and countries, to experience what it means to be human in a different context than the one in which they were raised.

Otherwise they might grow up to be like the thoroughly walled-in Mitt Romney, who could only contemplate the superiority of his own culture when he traveled to other countries.

My goodness....
The lie to your argument is that he assaulted a woman, no more or less. That's unconscionable. Is there something about woman beating being unacceptable that you don't understand? If so God help you.
"...Ravens fans gave Rice a loud ovation during a preseason game."  Cheers for this guy?

And the characters allowed were not sufficient for me to add:  when I was pressed for time, I was an afficiando of a cook book entitled: 365 Easy One Dish Meals.  At the dinner table, these one dish concoctions were described as "Mystery Meals". by the little cannibals I was able to share a meal with.

When I clicked on the comments, I was expecting to read a number of “scolds”. I was not disappointed. The study itself was poorly conceived, poorly written and anecdotal at best. It conflated too many issues (poverty, working hours, single parents, access to affordable and healthy food, modern school and work schedules, the burden of extra jobs and extra curricular activities, and other factors).
I have an undergrad. in Nutrition Science, not "Home Ec.". It was general chemistry, organic chemistry, biochemistry, nutritional biochemistry, biostatistics, physiological chemistry, clinical nutrition, graduate and undergraduate courses, with clinical rotations in a number of different hospitals I left the field because I felt like the application of the science was seriously lagging. I ended up practicing law.

It seems to me that the issues are: what comprises a healthy diet for most people? Are those foods available and affordable? If not, what policy changes are necessary to support sustainable agricultural practices that benefit everyone in the supply chain, and not just the wealthy? We can solve these problems so far as we agree we are in this together... and we are.

"Michael Vick went to jail over dog fighting. What does that tell you about the American Justice system? A dog is worth more than a black woman!"

No, but a woman can report the abuse, press charges, and leave her abuser. A dog can do none of those things, and is therefore arguably the more vulnerable victim. (That said, IMHO, both Michael Vick *and* Ray Rice should rot in prison.)
You're asking the wrong question. Why didn't the police arrest him? THAT is the question. It is not "political correctness" to have consequences after physically attacking someone.

Unfortunately, Janay Palmer's safety is now in greater jeopardy than before, especially because controlling and violent men rarely admit culpability. It's quite likely he would blame her for his football career demise and beat her even more.

Hee hee I sat for several minutes typing Rhein / Rhine / Rhein / Rhine, not knowing what to do with what I knew must be the "right" word.
Shise! Sheisse! Scheit!
smells the same by any name

I think it was just an excuse for the NFL to get it right.  They didn't expect the degree of outrage spurred on by the first video, and they jumped on this film as a way to do the right thing while still saving face about their initial poor judgement.
Not  understanding your logic. Rice should get his job back because the Ravens didn't do the right thing until now?

Very interesting point. A violent sport cannot expect it's violent players to suddenly turn off all violence when they step off the football field. Coupled with possible brain injury, even of the subtle kind, and possible roid useage, it could be the players need help, not condemnation and punishment.
They need both.

The NFL should be working closely with families, wives and girlfriends who accuse players of domestic violence.
Not only is it morally despicable, the rage and impulsivity could be signs of traumatic brain injury or post-concussion brain changes.
This does not excuse Ray Rice. But his wife deserves the full support of the NFL, and it should do its part to make sure that its athletes who are acting out get the appropriate treatment, whether it's anger management, jail, a complete neurological workup, or all of the above.
And families of athletes in high-impact sports should be educated and encouraged to let the league know if they see these changes at home--without fear of reprisal or lost contracts.
Why so extreme? How about a healthy middle-ground.

I couldn't care less for football, but I don't think we have to ban it. But we do need to stop glorifying these guys as "heroes" just because they get paid ridiculous sums of money for running real fast with a football. Otherwise they'll literally get away with murder (remember OJ) -- and look at the message that sends to all the young pro-athlete wannabees who idolize them.
The solution is not to ban Ray Rice, but to ban football, and all contact "sports", that serve no purpose other than to glorify violence between people.
mikenh, you need to reassess based on the relative power of each party here. Your assessment is profoundly clueless. It's called asymmetric power.
Why would she rhrow the book at him? Judging from the bystanders reaction, the security guards, the team and then Goodell, why would she think anyone would help her?

As so much of Mr. Brooks' recent writings, it seems to be removed from the "reality" which most of us experience.
I was fortunate enough to have gotten a very good education, even including a two year stint (Masters) at an "elite" university. But I certainly did not receive there, nor did I expect to receive there, a "moral education". It is typical of the presumptuousness of Mr. Brooks and his "class", that they think only through attendance at elite universities can one hope to become a "moral", a complete person, "an integrated self".

I do however, agree that America's "elite universities", be they private our state, have become expert at turning out "excellent sheep", perfectly tuned to fit into the mind-numbing, amoral machinery that is the "free market system". It is often the people who drop out of these zombie factories who become self-actualized, complete people.

The question, "just what is it that's worth wanting" is something that no modern university is equipped to answer. The students are too busy with "spring break" and binge drinking...
This is like when we do our addresses in Excel and they don't format the field correctly - all New Englanders get cheated out of their initial zero!
